{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3613057,"name":"Stephen Kalogiannis ","username":"sk2983","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sk2983/{size}/135585_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-05T17:09:31.486Z","cooked":"

Looking for some help on achieving something I have been playing with in SolidWorks for a few weeks now.

At the component level I have it working the way I want it to. I have a file property called Hole Diameter, where I can input a value and the diameter changes with the click of the rebuild button. See below:

image1677×206 8.81 KB

image736×679 18.6 KB

In the assembly I have multiple different components using the hole diameter to define its dimension, what I would like to do, is within the assembly file properties, use a callout similar to what I do on the component level, and have all the derived dimensions change with the click of the rebuild button. Currently the only way I have been able to do it is to go into each individual component and change its file properties dimension to the new hole diameter. This seems to be because the component is always calling back to the components file properties rather than the assemblies file properties. Anyone ever dealt with this.

This is actually something I did in college for my senior design project. The technique I used is to create a text file with your global variables and link it to your model. Here are a few useful resources to get you started:

Article from GoEngineer, a SOLIDWORKS VAR.

YouTube video I just found that looks correct.

My senior design project paper (see Appendix D and you can also download the zip of the model to see the text file).

Yeah, I highly recommend a separate global variable file. I particularly like it when working with tab and slot or plywood construction, you can model everything with a nominal thickness and router bit then update the models easily when you measure the actual material thickness or if you need to switch the cutter. Generally really useful when you want to start the modeling before all the measurements are nailed down.

Another technique is called “master modeling.” This Old Tony has an educational and entertaining video going over this methodology: https://youtu.be/LrPggPn5BB0?si=o2KMSplUlkvPkDll

TLDW: Create a master part that consists of sketches of the critical or shared geometry. Import that master part into each subsidiary part you are designing and reference the subsidiary parts off of the master sketches. Thus letting multiple parts easily share parametric geometry.

To add onto this, Can you make equations, drive configuration selections within as assembly?

For example I have an assembly that contains a part with 4 different configuration, the configuration for simplicity sakes is the depth of a hole 9mm 8mm,7mm,6mm. What I would like to do is using material thickness as my driving global variable have it auto select the appropriate configuration based off the inputed material thickness value. So I can do this with the equation =if(“materialthickness” <3,9mm,8mm) which will give me the auto changing part.

This give me close to what I am looking for, but then I loose my configuration names because my configurations are the different blanks I have available. So when I bring the assembly into my drawing and make my BOM the wrong blank is selected because I am changing the dimension of the configuration rather then simply switching to the correct configuration.

Hopefully this makes sense?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-11T19:16:38.546Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":18.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501257,"topic_slug":"file-properties-at-assembly-level-vs-component-level","display_username":"Stephen Kalogiannis ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18265,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/file-properties-at-assembly-level-vs-component-level/501257/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3652161,"name":"Rachael Naoum","username":"RachaelN","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rachaeln/{size}/241722_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-13T02:10:09.483Z","cooked":"

I’m not aware of any method of using equations to insert a specific component into an assembly, unfortunately. For your case here, I would recommend creating configurations of the assembly and then change the configuration of the part in each assembly config. So in your example, you would have 4 assembly configurations, using a different configuration of that part in each of them.

Without knowing much about your specific model, I would say you can probably use equations, mates, or other constraints in such a way that they will intentionally fail when not using the correct configuration. This will tell you, the designer, that you should try a different configuration. Though that might just be extra work, especially if you’ve already created different assembly configurations manually.

Hope this helps.
